intro: Gonzalea secunda, commonly known as the Mexican nightshade, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Solanaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like tomatoes and peppers. The plant produces small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically white or pale purple, and it bears berries that are toxic to humans and animals. Gonzalea secunda is often found in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to thrive in arid conditions. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and horticultural study.
